posts.name: Wihy
posts.cooked: Hi, I was wondering how different teams were doing constants Our team just uses a single Constants.java class and dumps everything there in nested classes with appropriate names, but this approach is not very organized I’d love for you guys to share how you do constants instead

posts.name: Alex He
posts.cooked: We are doing the same thing, but we created different classes inside the constant, like drive constant and arm constant.

We made a separate constants file for every subsystem (in a folder with that subsystem). We have a lot of constants, and most of them only have to do with a specific subsystem, so this approach makes sense and also combats clutter.

We also dedicated a file (RobotMap.kt) for constants like CAN IDs, channel numbers, port numbers, that sort of thing. Crescendo2024/src/main/kotlin/frc/robot/RobotMap.kt at main · Hamosad1657/Crescendo2024 · GitHub

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
We have a constant class for every subsystem.  This avoids merge collisions if different people are working on different subsystems.

We do have a CAN Conststants file though which in theory could collide but can constants don’t change much.  We did that so we could easily see what was used if we were adding another device.
We keep all our subsystem-specific constants in the robot container (for initialization stuff) or the subsystem itself. Most are private. Constants is only used for pose targets for aiming, etc.

posts.name: Justus
posts.cooked:
Constants exist as static members of their respective subsystem’s class definition

Keeping the stack trace easy to follow is extremely good practice even if a constants file is super common

Maybe that’s a hot take

Also OP may want to make a poll

posts.name: Rocky
posts.cooked: we loop the constants in nested interfaces Each sub interface is a specific subsystem

What are you doing that a constants file might end up in your stack trace? I guess on class load when all the static members are initialized, if they error the stack trace will point back there (not entirely sure what the stack trace looks like in this case tbh, but I feel like it would be similar to it being a static member in a non-constants file) but other than you are doing only variable access in that file

posts.cooked:
Okay, I think this is everything? lmk if I got what you meant incorrectly @Jus

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
We’ve been using a single Constants file with nested classes, but we’re thinking about moving private values into their respective subsystems because we don’t feel that having them as globals is gaining us anything.  The one thing we do like to have a global list of is CAN ids, so that we can quickly analyze error messages.

Our biggest problem with constants is how we handle multiple robots (e.g. practice vs competition).  To identify the robot, we create a file on the roboRIO.  We then have constants set for one robot, and then overridden for the other.  I don’t like this approach because it means “constants” are set in two places and it’s not always clear which one you should be changing.  Our plan for next year is to use the ternary conditional operator ( ?: ) for such cases so both values are in the same line.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: We have a constants class for each subsystem (now that we switched to Advantage Kit, we also have a constants class for each IO). Inside the class we declare the subsystem’s motors, their configurations, a SysID config, possibly a subsystem state Enum , and any other constant value / object. We also configure our hardware inside a static block in the constants class.

posts.name: Dan Langdon
posts.cooked: We do all one containers file with sub classes for different groups like field constansts shooter constants port constants ect
